tit.cmt: タイトルなので大文字を使いました。

sen.j: 砂かけ婆（すなかけばばあ）は、奈良県や兵庫県に伝わる妖怪。
sen.e: "Sunakake-babaa" is a specter said to inhabit Nara Prefecture and Hyogo Prefecture.
"Sunakake-babaa" is a specter said to inhabit Nara Prefecture and Hyogo Prefecture.
"Sunakake-babaa" is a specter said to inhabit Nara Prefecture and Hyogo Prefecture.

sen.j: 人が神社のそばや人通りの少ない森の中を歩いていると、砂を振りかけてくるものとされる。
sen.e: It is said that she throws down sand at people walking by shrines or in desolate woods.
It is said that she throws down sand at people walking by shrines or in desolate woods.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。
sen.e: It is said that she throws down sand at people walking by shrines or in desolate woods.

tit.cmt: 他のファイルと統一しました。

sen.j: 兵庫県西宮市では、ある松の木の上に砂かけ婆が出没し、砂をかける音が聞こえてきたものの、実際に砂が振りかかってくることはなかったという。
sen.e: It is said that one day in Nishinomiya City, Hyogo Prefecture, Sunakake-babaa appeared on a pine tree and was heard throwing sand, but that actually no sand fell on anybody there.
It is said that in Nishinomiya City, Hyogo Prefecture, Sunakake-babaa appeared on a pine tree and was heard throwing sand, but actually no sand fell on anybody there.
sen.cmt: One dayを削除しました。Thatを削除しました。スペースを削除しました。
sen.e: It is said that in Nishinomiya City, Hyogo Prefecture, Sunakake-babaa appeared on a pine tree and was heard throwing sand, but actually no sand fell on anybody there.

sen.j: 兵庫県尼崎市の稲荷神社でも、夜に鳥居の下をくぐると上から砂をかけられるといわれ、また同市内の庄下川でも砂かけの怪異があったという。
sen.e: It is also said that if one walks through the gate of an Inari-jinja shrine in Amagasaki City, Hyogo Prefecture, sand will be thrown at him and a mysterious event in which sand was thrown at somebody is said to have occurred by the Shoge River running through the city.

It is also said that sand is thrown down at those walking under the gate of Inari-jinja Shrine in Amagasaki City, Hyogo Prefecture, and the mysterious event of sand-throwing is said to have occurred by Shoge River which runs through the city.

It is also said that sand is thrown down at those walking under the gate of Inari-jinja Shrine in Amagasaki City, Hyogo Prefecture, and the mysterious event of sand-throwing is said to have occurred by Shoge River which runs through the city.

sen.j: 誰も姿を見たことがないといわれ、絵巻などにも描かれていないために姿形は不明。
sen.e: Since no one have seen Sunakake-babaa and there is no Emaki (picture scroll) or other records describing her, it is not known what she looks like.
Since no one has seen Sunakake-babaa and there is no Emaki (picture scroll) or other records describing her, it is not known what she looks like.
sen.cmt: 動詞を修正しました。スペースを削除しました。
sen.e: Since no one has seen Sunakake-babaa and there is no Emaki (picture scroll) or other records describing her, it is not known what she looks like.

sen.j: 自分の醜さを嫌って姿を人前に現さないともいう。
sen.e: She is said to conceal herself from people in disgust of her own ugliness.
She is said to conceal herself from people in disgust of her own ugliness.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。
sen.e: She is said to conceal herself from people in disgust of her own ugliness.

sen.j: 近年の書籍の妖怪画では便宜上その名の通り老婆の姿で描かれることが多いが、老婆の妖怪とする説、タヌキやイタチといった小動物の仕業とする説がある。
sen.e: Although in many of modern pictures of specters, she is conveniently depicted as an old woman as her name suggests, some believe that it is small animals such as Japanese minks or raccoon dogs who throw sand while others believe it a specter of an old woman.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although in many modern pictures of specters she is conveniently depicted as an old woman as her name suggests, some believe that it is small animals such as Japanese minks or raccoon dogs that throw sand while others believe it to be the work of a specter of an old woman.
sen.cmt: コンマを削除しました。Whoをthatにしました。To be the work ofを追加しました。スペースを削除しました。
sen.e: Although in many modern pictures of specters she is conveniently depicted as an old woman as her name suggests, some believe that it is small animals such as Japanese minks or raccoon dogs that throw sand while others believe it to be the work of a specter of an old woman.

sen.j: 実際には小動物が正体とする話の方が多い。
sen.e: In fact, more stories suggest that it is small animals.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In fact, more stories suggest that it is small animals.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。
sen.e: In fact, more stories suggest that it is small animals.

sen.j: 前述の西宮市や尼崎市の砂かけ婆は、名前は婆だが実際にはタヌキとされる。
sen.e: Sunakake-babaa in the above mentioned cities of Nishinomiya and Amagasaki is referred to as an old woman by name but it is actually explained as Japanese raccoons.
Sunakake-babaa in the above mentioned cities of Nishinomiya and Amagasaki is referred to as an old woman by name but is actually explained to be Japanese raccoons.
sen.cmt: Itを削除しました。Asをto beにしました。スペースを削除しました。
sen.e: Sunakake-babaa in the above mentioned cities of Nishinomiya and Amagasaki is referred to as an old woman by name but is actually explained to be Japanese raccoons.

sen.j: また青森県津軽地方、新潟県、愛知県、福岡県では砂撒き狸（すなまきだぬき）というタヌキが同様に夜道で砂をかけてくるという。
sen.e: Similarly, inTsugaru region of Aomori Prefecture, Niigata Prefecture, Aichi Prefecture and Fukuoka Prefecture, it is said that raccoon dogs called Sunamaki-danuki (sand-throwing raccoon dog) throw sand at people.
In Tsugaru region of Aomori Prefecture and Niigata, Aichi and Fukuoka Prefectures, it is said that raccoon dogs called Sunamaki-danuki (sand-throwing raccoon dog) similarly throw sand at people.
sen.cmt: スペースを追加しました。スペースを削除しました。Similarlyを移動しました。Prefectureを削除しました。
sen.e: In Tsugaru region of Aomori Prefecture and Niigata, Aichi and Fukuoka Prefectures, it is said that raccoon dogs called Sunamaki-danuki (sand-throwing raccoon dog) similarly throw sand at people.

sen.j: 新潟の佐渡島の妙照寺に住む老いた砂撒き狸は信心深く、佐渡に配流された順徳天皇のもとを子の忠子内親王が訪れる際、荒れた道に砂を撒いてならし清めたといわれ、砂撒きを見た人は忠子内親王が父に逢いに来た日だと知ったという。
sen.e: According to a story, an old Sunamaki-danuki living in Myosho-ji Temple in Sadoga-shima Island, Niigata Prefecture, was so deeply religious that it smoothed out rough roads and purified them by spreading sand on the roads when Imperial Princess Tadako visited there to see her father, Emperor Juntoku who had been exiled to Sadoga-shima Island, and people there, seeing the sand-throwing by the raccoon dog, learned that the imperial princess visited her father that day.

According to one story, an old Sunamaki-danuki living in Myosho-ji Temple in Sadoga-shima Island, Niigata Prefecture, was so deeply religious that it smoothed out rough roads and purified them by spreading sand on them when Imperial Princess Tadako visited there to see her father, Emperor Juntoku who had been exiled to Sadoga-shima Island, and people there, seeing the sand-throwing, learned that the imperial princess visited her father that day.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。Aをoneにしました。The roadsをthemにしました。By the raccoon dogを削除しました。
sen.e: According to one story, an old Sunamaki-danuki living in Myosho-ji Temple in Sadoga-shima Island, Niigata Prefecture, was so deeply religious that it smoothed out rough roads and purified them by spreading sand on them when Imperial Princess Tadako visited there to see her father, Emperor Juntoku who had been exiled to Sadoga-shima Island, and people there, seeing the sand-throwing, learned that the imperial princess visited her father that day.

sen.j: 徳島県板野郡撫養町小桑島字前組ではこうしたタヌキを砂ふらし（すなふらし）といい、人に砂をかけることで方向感覚を狂わせて道を迷わせ、水辺に落としてしまうという。
sen.e: At Kokuwajima aza Maegumi, Muya-cho, Itano County, Tokushima Prefecture, such a raccoon dog is called Sunafurashi (sand throwing ghost) and believed to throw sand at people to deprive them of the sense of direction, causing them to lose their way and fall into the water.

At Kokuwajima aza Maegumi, Muya-cho, Itano County, Tokushima Prefecture, such a raccoon dog is called Sunafurashi (sand throwing ghost) and believed to throw sand at people to deprive them of the sense of direction, causing them to lose their way and fall into the water.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。
sen.e: At Kokuwajima aza Maegumi, Muya-cho, Itano County, Tokushima Prefecture, such a raccoon dog is called Sunafurashi (sand throwing ghost) and believed to throw sand at people to deprive them of the sense of direction, causing them to lose their way and fall into the water.

sen.j: 千葉県では利根川のほとりで猫ほどの大きさの小動物が木に登り、通行人に砂を振りまいたことがあったという。
sen.e: In Chiba Prefecture, it is reported that a small animal as small as a cat climbed onto a tree by the Tone River and sprinkled sand on passengers walking under the tree.
In Chiba Prefecture, it was reported that an animal as small as a cat climbed onto a tree by the Tone River and sprinkled sand on travelers walking under the tree.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。時制を修正しました。Smallを削除しました。Passengersをtravelersにしました。
sen.e: In Chiba Prefecture, it was reported that an animal as small as a cat climbed onto a tree by the Tone River and sprinkled sand on travelers walking under the tree.

sen.j: 新潟県三条市の翁坂では砂撒きイタチといって、砂をかける以外に人の蝋燭の火を奪うといい、火取り魔の正体であるともいう。
sen.e: At Okinazaka slope, Sanjo City, Niigata Prefecture, it is said that Sunamaki-itachi (sand-throwing mink) not only throws sand at people but also deprives them of candle flames and is referred to as "hitorima" (fire-taking demon)

At Okinazaka slope in Sanjo City, Niigata Prefecture, it is said that Sunamaki-itachi (sand-throwing mink) not only throws sand at people but also deprives them of candle flames and is considered to be the true identity of the hitorima (fire-taking demon).
sen.cmt: ピリオドを追加しました。コンマを削除しました。最終部分を修正しました。
sen.e: At Okinazaka slope in Sanjo City, Niigata Prefecture, it is said that Sunamaki-itachi (sand-throwing mink) not only throws sand at people but also deprives them of candle flames and is considered to be the true identity of the hitorima (fire-taking demon).

sen.j: 滋賀県では小動物ではなく婆の妖怪とする例があり、砂ほりばばあ（砂を放る婆の意）といって、ある竹薮の一角に婆が住み着き、そこを通る村人に砂を投げつけたという。
sen.e: In Shiga Prefecture, there is an example in which it is believed that not a small animal but a specter of an old woman called Sunahori-babaa (sand-throwing hag), who used to live at a corner of a bamboo grove and throw sand at people passing by.

In Shiga Prefecture, there is an example in which it is believed that not a small animal but a specter of an old woman called Sunahori-babaa (another name for sand-throwing hag) lived at a corner of a bamboo grove and threw sand at people passing by.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。説明を追加しました。コンマを削除しました。時制を修正しました。
sen.e: In Shiga Prefecture, there is an example in which it is believed that not a small animal but a specter of an old woman called Sunahori-babaa (another name for sand-throwing hag) lived at a corner of a bamboo grove and threw sand at people passing by.

sen.j: 名称の「婆」は老婆ではなく、汚物を意味する方言の「ババ」を由来とする説もある。
sen.e: There is a theory that the word "babaa" included in the name does not mean an old woman but is derived from a slang word "baba" meaning slops.
There is a theory that the word "babaa" included in the name does not mean an old woman but is derived from a slang word "baba" meaning slops.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。
sen.e: There is a theory that the word "babaa" included in the name does not mean an old woman but is derived from a slang word "baba" meaning slops.

sen.j: また滋賀の東近江市八日市でも何者かが川から砂を投げつけ、砂に当たると足がたたなくなったり体調が悪くなったりした。
sen.e: Also in Yokaichi, Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture, it is said that someone threw sand from a river at people and that people got bit by the sand were disabled from rising to their feet or became ill.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Also in Yokaichi, Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture, it is said that someone threw sand at people from a river and that those hit by the sand lost use of their legs or became ill.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。At peopleを移動しました。Peopleをthoseにしました。後半を訳し直しました。
sen.e: Also in Yokaichi, Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture, it is said that someone threw sand at people from a river and that those hit by the sand lost use of their legs or became ill.

sen.j: 妖怪研究家・山口敏太郎は、奈良県ではで砂を雨に見立てた広瀬神社の「砂かけ祭り」という雨乞いの神事や、砂をかけ合って「砂かけ婆だ」と囃し立てる祭りのある地域もあることから、そのような神事や祭りが砂かけ婆の伝承に繋がった可能性を示唆している。
sen.e: Toshitaro YAMAGUCHI, a student of specters, referring to a ritual of amagoi (praying for rain) called Sunakake (sand-throwing) festival held at the Hirose-jinja Shrine or a regional festival of people throwing sand to each other while calling out "sunakake-babaa", suggests a possibility that such a ritual and a event led to survival of legends about Sunakake-babaa.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Toshitaro YAMAGUCHI, a scholar of specters, referring to a ritual of amagoi (praying for rain) called Sunakake festival held at Hirose-jinja Shrine where sand is used as a symbol of rain or regional festivals where people throw sand at each other while calling out "sunakake-babaa," suggests that such rituals and events have led to the survival of legends about Sunakake-babaa.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。冠詞を修正しました。student.をscholarにしました。Originalからの情報を追加しました。
sen.e: Toshitaro YAMAGUCHI, a scholar of specters, referring to a ritual of amagoi (praying for rain) called Sunakake festival held at Hirose-jinja Shrine where sand is used as a symbol of rain or regional festivals where people throw sand at each other while calling out "sunakake-babaa," suggests that such rituals and events have led to the survival of legends about Sunakake-babaa.

sen.j: 鳥が空を飛びながら体に付着した砂を落としたものが、こうした砂かけの怪異の正体だとする説もある。
sen.e: Another theory is that such mysterious events of throwing sand can be attributed to birds flying in the sky from the bodies of which sand fell off.
One theory behind this strange phenomenon of sand-throwing is birds flying in the sky and dropping sand that had been stuck on their bodies.
One theory behind this strange phenomenon of sand-throwing is birds flying in the sky and dropping sand that had been stuck on their bodies.

sen.j: 民俗学者・柳田國男の著書『妖怪談義』に記述がある妖怪のひとつで、その話の出所は柳田の友人、沢田四郎作（さわたしろうさく）医学博士の『大和昔譚』である。
sen.e: Sunakake-babaa is one of specters described in "Yokai Dangi" (lecture about specters) written by Kunio YANAGIDA and the story about Sunakake-babaa in the book is extracted from "Yamato Sekitan" (Old stories of Japan) written by his friend, Shiro SAWADA, M.D.

Sunakake-babaa is one of specters described in "Yokai Dangi" (Lecture about Specters) written by folklorist Kunio YANAGIDA and the story in the book is extracted from "Yamato Sekitan" (Old Stories of Japan) written by his friend, Shiro SAWADA, M.D.
sen.cmt: Foldloristを追加しました。スペースを削除しました。About sunakake-babaaを削除しました。本のタイトルを大文字にしました。
sen.e: Sunakake-babaa is one of specters described in "Yokai Dangi" (Lecture about Specters) written by folklorist Kunio YANAGIDA and the story in the book is extracted from "Yamato Sekitan" (Old Stories of Japan) written by his friend, Shiro SAWADA, M.D.

sen.j: 同書には「おばけのうちにスナカケババといふものあり、人淋しき森のかげ、神社のかげを通れば、砂をバラバラふりかけておどろかすといふもの、その姿見たる人なし」とある。
sen.e: SAWADA's book describes that specters include one called Sunakake-babaa, who surprises people by throwing sand at them walking by desolate woods or shrines, but that no one has seen her.
SAWADA's book says that there is a ghost called Sunakake-baba who surprises people by throwing sand at them while walking by desolate woods or shrines, but that no one has seen her.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。Spectorをghostにしました。Describeをsayにしました。
sen.e: SAWADA's book says that there is a ghost called Sunakake-baba who surprises people by throwing sand at them while walking by desolate woods or shrines, but that no one has seen her.

sen.j: 水木しげるによる漫画『ゲゲゲの鬼太郎』で鬼太郎と共に戦う正義の妖怪としての活躍により一躍、全国的に有名な妖怪となった。
sen.e: Sunakake-babaa became instantly famous nationwide by a comic book titled "Ge-Ge-Ge no Kitaro"written by Shigeru MIZUKI in which Sunakake-babaa is a specter who fights against enemies for justice together with the main character, Kitaro.

Sunakake-babaa became instantly famous nationwide by a comic book titled "Ge-Ge-Ge no Kitaro" written by Shigeru MIZUKI, in which Sunakake-babaa is a specter who fights against enemies for justice together with the main character, Kitaro.
sen.cmt: スペースを削除しました。スペースを追加しました。コンマを追加しました。
sen.e: Sunakake-babaa became instantly famous nationwide by a comic book titled "Ge-Ge-Ge no Kitaro" written by Shigeru MIZUKI, in which Sunakake-babaa is a specter who fights against enemies for justice together with the main character, Kitaro.

sen.j: また同漫画をはじめとする水木の妖怪画では、その名の通り和服姿の老婆として描かれているが、妖怪研究家・京極夏彦によれば佐渡島の郷土芸能・鬼太鼓の面がモデルとされる。
sen.e: Moreover, in MIZUKI's pictures of specters including the above-mentioned comic, Sunakake-babaa is depicted as an old woman and according to Natsuhiko KYOGOKU, a student of specters, MIZUKI's image of Sunakake-babaa is based on a mask used in a local performing art of Sadoga-shima Island called ondeko.

In MIZUKI's pictures of specters including the above-mentioned comic, Sunakake-babaa is depicted as an old woman wearing traditional Japanese clothing as suggested by the name, but according to Natsuhiko KYOGOKU, a scholar of specters, the appearance is based on a mask used in a local performing art of Sadoga-shima Island called ondeko.
sen.cmt: Originalにより忠実になるよう修正しました。スペースを削除しました。
sen.e: In MIZUKI's pictures of specters including the above-mentioned comic, Sunakake-babaa is depicted as an old woman wearing traditional Japanese clothing as suggested by the name, but according to Natsuhiko KYOGOKU, a scholar of specters, the appearance is based on a mask used in a local performing art of Sadoga-shima Island called ondeko.
